newsitem.title: FINLAND: Finnish interest rates near right level - premier.
newsitem.headline: Finnish interest rates near right level - premier.

text.p: Finnish interest rates were near a level "where they should be" considering Finland's unemployment problem, Prime Minister Paavo Lipponen said.

"The government has staked out its medium-term goals very clearly. The basic target is to achieve a medium-term period of growth, which will lower unemployment significantly from the current level," Lipponen said in a seminar, according to a copy of his prepared speech.

Many positive things had happened over the past year, he said. "Interest rates have approached the level where they should be, considering the difficult unemployment situation," he said but did not elaborate.
The prepared speech made no reference to the exchange rate of the markka or the timetable of a coming decision whether to peg it to Europe's exchange rate mechanism.

Instead, Lipponen spoke in broad terms about his five-party coalition's economic policy programme. Halting state indebtedness, keeping inflation in check and interest rates low were key government objectives, he said.
Finland had a good chance to reach its target of slightly more than three percent annual growth on average in 1997-2000, Lipponen said.
"I am emphasising that the question is explicitly about average growth, not that the increase in production would be completely even from quarter to quarter," he said.
He said he was convinced that the economic policy pursued by the government would bear fruit. Signs of strengthening domestic growth were visible, he said.
Recovering domestic demand would be crucial to combat the current mass unemployment, he said.
